div.p:
Then we are agreed about the little plays - an
hundred guineas for a vol volume to match the size
of Parents Asssistant. and permission to me to
send any Ms. manuscript over to America as soon as I
deliver it to you - So far so good. But observe I
do not wish that the plays should appear as a
new work, only as an additional volume of a
new edition of Parents Assistant. You do not say any thing
in reply to what I said about your letting the
purchases of former Editions of Parents assistant buy
this vol. volume of plays separately to make up their set if
they choose. I lay stress on this as I think it but
fair to said purchasers - You need not send
Parents assistant to us to be recorrected for a
new edition as we have no new corrections to make
But I should like to know what size you
propose your new edn
edition to be and what number of vols. volumes

Wherever you are standing or sitting when
you receive this letter, be pleased to issue immediate
orders that search should be made in your house
for a ms manuscript which I sent you in 1820, when you
you were printing the sequel of Rosamond -

The ms is called The Dame School" - We had
once intended to insert it in Rosamond, but we
thought it best on second thoughts to reserve it
for a vol of Plays - You never returned me the ms

When you have found it will you make your
printer cast it off and see and tell me how many
pages it will make of the size you mean to make
your new edition - When that is done, send the
ms in one or two packets as maybe most conven
- ient convenient directed to the East of Rosse Parsonstown.
At the same time write and tell me whether
you accede to what I say about the mode of
publication of the little plays -

You take no notice at all of my
request that you would send me various books
I have repeatedly written for and that you would
send me the parcel of books from France wh
Either is at your house or Captn Beauforts.
And ask yourself whether it be reasonable that I
should go without all the books I want - rather than
employ any other bookseller than Mr Hunter who
will not take the trouble to send what is desired.
div.closer:
I am dear Sir-
very truly (but not stupidly
or blindly), yours sincerely
Maria Edgeworth
